definition: to change one's tune/to modify one's previous remark/to change the way one addresses sb (as when one marries and starts to call one's husband's parents 爸爸[ba4 ba5] and 媽媽|妈妈[ma1 ma5])
to change/to alter/to transform/to correct
mouth/classifier for things with mouths (people, domestic animals, cannons, wells etc)/classifier for bites or mouthfuls
a gift of money given by parents on both sides after a wedding, to their new daughter-in-law or son-in-law

sentences.english: Blevins recalled. "I just knew I didn't want to quit."
sentences.chinese: 这时布来温又改口到，不，但我又不能退学。

sentences.english: I also hurriedly say you understand?
sentences.chinese: 我又急忙改口说您都听懂了？

sentences.english: Consistency. Most people prefer to keep their word.

to blurt out/to let slip (an indiscreet remark)
slip of the tongue/indiscretion/to blurt out a secret
to blurt out/to let slip
to answer back sarcastically (idiom)/to retort
to come to oneself/to come to realize/to come to see the truth/to wake up to reality
to retort/to refute

to stop/to halt
implication
to renege/to go back (on a deal)/to back out (of a promise)
to help to resolve a dispute/to smooth things over
to make fun of
to feel embarrassed/to find it embarrassing/to be sorry (for inconveniencing sb)
